Sara makes breakfast as her husband PETER, 40, walks in f the bedroom, plastering an unruly boyish cowlick which be the strain and age in his eyes. He’s off to work.

He’s okay now. He’s asleep.

No it’s alright - I’m still wired from driving - and Wendy’s helping. WENDY - Sara's 17 year old niece - enters trailing the RAUCOUS SOUNDS OF KIDS behind her.

Take these pancakes in to the hungry hordes. Wendy exits. And through the open door we catch a quick glimpse of two younger kids at the table. And a bleary an pale faced Matt stumbling out of a bedroom.
It’s not good. One of these nights you’re gonna drive off the road you'll be so tired.

Find a rental in Connecticut, near the Hospital. We’1l make it work.
You mean it? What’1l you do? How will we afford it?
Come on weekends. Take a second mortgage on our second mortgage. Whatever it takes.
We’re gonna make it through this, right?
Definitely. His eyes, though, have none of the certainty of his words
Victorian Gothic Hospital with concrete ‘70’s additions. SUPER: St. Michael's Hospital. Goatswood, Connecticut. June 20. 10:00 A.M.
Sara with the Oncologist, DR. Brooks.
He’s doing great.
He vomited twice more this morning. That’s doing great?

I don’t want to waste your time. What are you asking? The man turns around - AZIZ SINGH, realtor. Warm, persuas

It just needs some love and care...
Singh guides Sara past the time-faded wallpaper and chipp paint of a once elegant old interior.
---and a good family to bring it back to life.
And you don’t mind children?
Where would we be without them? On a cold empty rock. Suddenly - a RUMBLING, GROANING CLANKING sound. MR. SINGH (CONT’D) Old houses are like old stomachs. They make a lot of noise.

It’s everything we need. And then some. It’s beautiful, spacious, affordable. I mean, it’s too good to be true. So what’s the catch? Matt seems to be hanging upside down - as hot lava flows his veins - he slowly rotates - But in fact he is not mov

The catch? Yes, well it does have a somewhat peculiar history... - it’s the camera spinning: Matt’s in a chair attached to machine; tubes from the machine give multiple injections simultaneously. While another filters his blood.
Sara nearly at the end of her rope, talking to Peter.
I saw one that was almost perfect but...it just wasn’t quite right.  14 INT. SARA’S CAR - A BEAT LATER 14 Driving home. She looks at Matt in the rear view mirror.
They say you might have some body ache - but no nausea.

(through clenched teeth) Doctor says to patient; I got bad news. You’ve got cancer. And you’ve got Alzheimer’s.’ Patient says ‘Whew, least I don’t have cancer.’ Sara laughs not to cry. As each tiny bump sends paroxysms pain through Matt’s body. MATT (CONT’D) At least I don’t have nausea. He’s putting on a brave face - but his groans can’t be stifled. Every small bump in the road sends shockwaves of pain through his young body. Sara steals glances in the r view mirror at him - and it tears at her heart. She turns car around and heads back the way they came...

Mr. Singh stands out front with Sara, near her car. We se he’s brought a big mattress, two sleeping bags, a portabl and even some take-away food. Both of them helping a frail Matt out of the back seat of the car, one putting a blanket around his shoulders.
I don’t know how to thank you. He leans in to her - out of Matt’s hearing.
Really, don’t worry - and remember - a house is just bricks and wood and plaster. That’s all. Anything else - is just imagination...
Two sleeping bags lie on the mattress beside the table.  17 18 10. Matt, half asleep, watches TV. Behind him we see Sara on phone.

I made a decision. You weren’t there. She pulls the phone into the next room - so Matt can’t he As Matt nods off we MOVE IN on the TV screen. In reflecti we can see Matt in front of it- but also - something else Someone standing behind him. Or is it just the flickering ghosts of bad TV reception? Sara steps into the next room - so Matt doesn’t hear.
You didn’t have to hear him groaning, Peter. I just couldn’t take it.

Looking down on Sara and Matt. Each in their own sleeping bag. But lying close. The dark room seems filled with muf voices. The walls seem to whisper like faint swarms of be A close POV of the sleeping mother and son - as of someon standing right over them... Matt stirs, looks up uneasily at the spot where a second it seemed someone was standing observing them. Nothing th Matt slips out of bed as quietly as he can. He starts int the nearest bathroom - but realizes the sound will wake h so he goes looking for another one upstairs.
He finds a bathroom. He leans over to retch. Splashes col water in his face. Then freezes. Did he hear something?
Matthew.

Mom? He opens the door. No one’s there. He pads back downstair  19 20 21 11. INT. PARLOR —- CONTINUOUS 19 But he sees she’s still sound asleep. He’s about to get i his sleeping bag when again he hears--
Matthew... From behind him this time. He tries to follow the sound.

He steps into the darkened stairwell. Suddenly the silenc torn by a GRINDING sound - from deep inside the house: th clanging of old elevator chains... Stepping out of the darkness of the stairs, Matt thinks h sees a mirror - but then sees it is a half wood, half thi glass wall with a door. The mirror effect is because some seems to be standing on the other side of the glass.
He approaches - closer - cups his hands to try and see through the distorting glass -

Hello? Who’s there? Seen through the distorting glass: A face - impossible to if it is just a distorted reflection of his own face in t thick glass or another face on the other side looking bac him - blackened and burnt and mouth open in a scream as a hand jerks the head away by the hair -
- and it is Matt who SCREAMS as he jerks awake, woozy, hi face red and covered in sweat.
What? Wh-where? Sunlight pours in. A hand strokes his brow.
Honey? You alright?
Yeah. Just a dream. I guess.  22 23 24 25 12.
She gives him a can of protein shake.

Matt starts upstairs, checking out the rooms.

Matt steps into the first room. Faded Victorian wall pape covered with an intricate pattern of caged song birds. Th feeling is utterly lonely, and a place out of time. INT. DOWNSTAIRS PARLOR —- CONTINUOUS 25 Sara’s in the front parlor, damp dusting down the room an cabinets. She pulls at old built-in wooden cabinets benea the windows. They’re stuck shut from years of warping and dust. She pulls harder - and the wooden door opens, revea a cabinet filled with small frames stacked on their sides She pulls one out - then another - they’re old framed pho from the teens or twenties by the dress of the people - w recognize the photos - we saw them in the credit sequence - Twin boys sit one each on Mother and Father’s lap. The children seem stiff and awkward as dolls. - an old man in a bed - surrounded by family who all star into the camera - only his eyes are closed. - a mother and new born infant lie together as if sleepin - a family - Mother, Father, Three children. All sit froz before a painted backdrop of clouds as if seated in Heave Suddenly Sara recognizes what they are - DEAD PEOPLE. The looks around her and recognizes the room she’s standing i is the same as the room in which the photos were taken -s can make out the faded painted over clouds of the heavenl backdrop still visible beneath the fading paint on the wa and drops the photos on the floor, breaking the glass.  26 27 28 29 13.
Sara bends over the large garbage cans out back dumping t photos into the garbage cans. Looking around back at the house to make sure Matt hasn’t seen her.

In the hall Matt stops by small metal doors with a button opens the doors into a small elevator shaft covered insid with what looks like centuries of dust. He peers down int the blackness. He pulls a penny from his pocket and drops down the shaft. We hear it PINGING and KNOCKING all the w down...suddenly a GRINDING of GEARS and CLANKING CHAINS.
Stepping into the kitchen Sara hears the grinding elevato
Matt? She walks to the stairs and peers up to the hallway.
Matt? Did you pick a room?
Yeah. I did. The voice doesn’t come from upstairs. But from downstairs
Sara finds Matt in the middle of the basement.
Or it picked me.
What do you mean, it picked you?
I dunno. It’s the meds mom.
So, which room? (Matt gestures, this room) Down here?  30 31 14.
I like it. It’s nice and cool. And best of all, my own private toilet - nobody has to hear me.
You don’t need to hide from us.

Knowing everyone can hear me puking just makes me feel worse. Alright? Matt tries the locked door in the half-glass wall that divides the space. The door is not locked. And the knob turns. But it just won’t open. MATT (CONT’D) What do you think’s back here? They both have their faces pressed against the glass tryi to see in. HONKS and SHOUTS from upstairs startle them.
Hello? Anybody home?

Matt and his Dad behind the rented U-Haul, which is conne to a shiny late model pickup truck - Peter’s pride and jo Peter’s pulling boxes out of the back.
Hand me that one.
No, no —
I can - You might -  32 33 34 15.

Now I think this room would be a perfect girl’s room. INT. BEDROOM —- CONTINUOUS 33 The room with the caged birds on the wall.
Why do you say that?

Good light. Nice wall paper. And a big mirror. They both laugh, and as she closes the closet door with t mirror on it we see SUPER-BRIEF FLASH: A young man - wear very old fashioned clothes - stands staring sullenly at t

A little dark. But hey - I was a teenager once. Cool bachelor pad.
Cool pad? Dad, this is the 80's?
Trust me - the 70’s will be back. (Tries the door) What’s back here?  35 16.

THE BASEMENT —- SOME TIME LATER 35 Sara mops the floor of the room. As she moves backwards, glass wall is behind her. Matt comes down stairs - sees his Mom still cleaning and smiles and shakes his head - but then he sees: Behind her it seems he sees two figures back there. One a tall thin man. The other, a boy - about Matt's age. The s sullen boy we glimpsed in the mirror upstairs. They are b over tables. Working. Matt says nothing but takes a step closer and for a secon
In this exact same space a body'S exsanguinated, drained blood. The tall thin man and the boy are embalming a body Hosing the blood into a concave ditch that ends in a drai
Matt stifles a scream - his mother hears him and looks up from her mopping with a smile -

Honey? You feeling alright?  36 17. Matt looks up - the morticians are gone. He looks down at floor and sees a horrific red mess of congealing blood al around her mop. Noticing nothing Sara lifts the mop back into the water - squeezes it out - clear water pours out. Matt blinks and it’s all normal. But when she puts the mop back down on t floor: again the water turns a thick coagulated red.
Mom! She stops and looks up again - a bit annoyed now but tryi not to show it.
What now? He looks at the dripping mop - no blood, just water. All normal. And behind the window no figures leaning over cadavers. The floor is spotless.

Um, nothing - just, thanks - for cleaning my room. She gives him a peck on the cheek on her way out of the r Matt lingers in the door for a second - looking back at h room - daring it to show him something again.

Tending a barbecue grill, turns to look at Matt - who’s looking up at the just appearing stars in the night sky. Peter sees something in Matt’s face. Something vulnerable Fearful. Angry? He can’t tell. Maybe all three.

I remember when we used to go camping. When you were little. And every night you’d fall asleep counting the stars and could never finish. Used to drive you nuts. Matt just stares at him. He’s a long way from that kid no

Yeah. But then I learned. All the stars we see are already dead. We just haven’t gotten the news.  37 38 18. Peter, worried, has no reply to that as Matt turns and wa into the house. Passing Sara, who is coming out with burg buns. Sara saw the worried look on Matt’s face, and it is mirrored in her own worried expression.
Something on your mind?
Of course there’s something on my mind. There’s always something on my mind. The same as always. INT. MARY’S ROOM - LATER THAT NIGHT 37 Mary and Wendy are kneeling by the bed -
You get your own room - like a big girl- you sure you won’t be scared?
I don’t think so.
Good. Okay, you start.

Now I lay me down to sleep - As we hear the prayer we PAN ACROSS the shelf above her b lined with all her stuffed animals and dolls: including h favorite, a featureless soft thing, worn to almost nothin impossible to say whether it was once a teddy-bear or rab or what. Its remaining shoe-button eye hangs by a string. MARY O.S. If I should die before I wake... We continue out down the hall to the next room where -
I pray the Lord my soul to take. Billy’s a bit spooked. He closes his door most of the way He looks in the closet. Then checks under the bed too.  39 40 19.

On this moonless night the darkened house looms like a shadow’s shadow. Darker than the night itself. INT. MATT’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 40 Matt in bed, face covered in sweat. His closed eyes twitc from the force of rapid eye movement. Suddenly he sits upright in bed. Eyes still closed. Then they snap open. But blank and unseeing - staring not merely across the ro but across decades of time past into the glassed in room. MATT’S POV: In the next chamber he sees a tall thin man - the one he earlier saw embalming a body - AICKMAN - who now seems be over some writing on pale parchment. Beyond him the boy, JONAH - watches Aickman writing with look of growing horror - then looks up across the space a locks eyes with Matt - And suddenly it is as if Matt can see through Jonah's eye a_close vision of Aickman's strange writing: Aliguem Mortuum Suspiria Magical words and symbols fill the screen. Thin scratchin in red on parchment. Arcane words in an ancient languages necromancy. And as we see them, we hear them:

Aliquem mortuum suspiria, talis ordo tenebrum est. And suddenly we widen to see: Aickman is not writing on parchment - he is not writing at all - he is carving thes letters with a thin scalpel directly into the pale flesh an_ embalmed corpse!

.---per nomina sancta deus...Adonai, Alpha et Omega, Sabaoth... See now scores of incantations carved upon every inch of dead white flesh by the thin grey hands of Aickman Behind him, we glimpse several other bodies bound in clot and from arms and ankles sticking out we can see: They to are carved with signs and words.  41 42 43 20. The boy - JONAH - stares horrified - his face a mirror to Matt's face across the room staring blindly at the strang things happening right in his bedroom! And now we understand the shocked look of abject horror i the eyes of the boy Jonah who sees:
As Aickman's long fingers pull gently on the corpse's eye
stretching the delicate flesh out from the head. And with horrible SNIPPING sound -

INT. MATT’S BEDROOM —- CONTINUOUS 4l Matt’s own eyes, for the first time, blink. And he is suddenly awake. He looks around - disoriented. As if it w all just some horrific, and horrifically detailed, nightm He looks across the room - to the half glass divider - be which he saw - or dreamt he saw - such abominable things. Matt wipes the sleep from his eye and gets closer to the window - he sees nothing. He tries the door knob.
ow! He pulls his hand back. And we can see his skin blisterin as if he had grabbed burning metal.
From the back yard, looking at the kitchen windows. In th bright summer sun the place looks almost homey. Super: July 20th 8:30 am

Sara’s making breakfast. Matt’s there too, taking plates a cupboard and putting them on the counter. Then he gets silverware and carries it back to the dining room. As he starts to set the knives and forks around the table hears, faint but distinctly, VOICES. He can’t tell at fir  21. From the walls? The ceiling? Or is it the floor? Or all o them? He turns around, no one’s there. Shaking it out of his mind, Matt walks back to the kitche only to find the plates he set out on the counter are gon and they’re back in the cupboard where he got them. Sara at the stove, tending to the eggs and pancakes.
Why'd you put the plates back?
What?
I put the plates out and now --

I didn’t touch them, sweetie. Are you okay? Matt nods, then steps back to the cupboard. CRASH! He spi the plates are on the floor, broken. Sara hurries over. S also notes for the first time his hand - it looks burned.
I’m sorry honey. That was stupid of me. The dishes were too heavy for-
I didn’t drop them.
Then how -
I don’t know! I swear - I - saw - Sara touches his forehead, checking for fever.
Dr. Brooks said to tell him if you were seeing things. He said -

- I remember what he said. He said if I was seeing things - or even thinking weird things - it meant they'd drop me from the trial. We didn’t come this far, turn our lives upside down, move house, just to call it all off.  44 22.
But if you’re -
No Mom. It’s nothing. I’m not seeing things. I swear. Nothing's wrong. Really. I’m just tired. I remember now - I just left them sitting too close to the edge.
Well, alright. But you tell me if anything like that happens again. Promise?
Promise. Sorry I broke the dishes.

That’s alright sweetie. Your Grandmother used to kiss me when I broke a plate or a glass. Said it meant something worse won’t happen. INT. DR. BROOKS’S OFFICE - DAY 44 With Sara and Matt there, the Doctor, wearing latex glove gingerly probes the peeling skin on Matt’s hand.
His skin may well turn black. Start peeling off. Perfectly normal. It’s a bit early. But that could be a good sign. He pulls a thermometer out of Matt’s mouth.

No fever - excellent. Less nausea? Good. Even a bit of appetite. Outstanding. And no visual or auditory hallucinations or other behavioral abnormalities? She’s silent for a beat. The Doctor looks up at her, and Matt. Matt looks at her - worried she’s going to mention morning...
Anything? She hesitates for a beat, but only a beat.  45
No, no. Sorry I was just distracted. He’s fine, I guess. Considering. Matt nods in agreement.
Excellent. Then we can continue to stage two.

Matt sits in a room eith six Barcaloungers facing six tel visions. Each chair attached to one of the modules which controls the chemo. Some of the people, all in street clothes, in the other five chairs have already lost their hair. Some still look robust. Some will die, and soon. In the chair next to him a strangely young pair of eyes p curiously out of an older man’s face - POPESCU. Matt hears a SCRABBLING sound and looks down at the floor the right of his chair and sees with a jolt: A large blac CRAB scuttles across the floor and scrambles under the ch Matt looks around - no one else seems to have noticed. He leans over and tries to see under the chair. Nothing. And before he can sit back up a black claw whips out and closes on the soft part of his forearm -—
And he screams -—
Now that didn’t hurt.
A nurse pulls a needle out of his arm as Matt snaps awake the chemo room. The old man, Popescu, lays a reassuring h on his arm leans in conspiratorially close:
You were dreaming.
What? Oh. Yeah.  24.
And breathing heavy. Which of course can mean either a very bad dream. Or a very good one. Which was it?
I’ve had better. His eyes seem to look right into Matt - spreading a kind warmth as they do. MATT (CONT’D) Sometimes lately - It’s been hard.
What?
To tell which is a dream.
Are we men dreaming we’re butterflies? Or butterflies dreaming we’re men?
Do you ever...
What?
I dunno, see things? Hear things. Things that... aren’t - that can’t be - there? Popescu makes a zipping gesture at his lips - and turns a invisible key and tosses it away.

Don’t ever tell them you can see things. They won’t understand. When my wife was dying - the whole last day - I sat there praying and crying. She never once looked at me. Just looked all around her - as if at all the others in the room - but we were alone. Or so I thought. Now I know better. She was where we are. In the valley.  46 47 25.
The Valley?
Of the shadow of death. And you know what to do when you find yourself in the valley of the shadow of death?
What?
Easy. Fear no evil. He hands Matt a card: Fr. Nicholas Popescu.
If you need to talk, call me. Any time.
The children all asleep, Sara’s still awake at a table covered in bills and insurance forms. She’s on the phone talking to Peter:

Right, this was gonna be free. Sixty bucks for five pills... No, that they’1ll cover. But not the follow-ups... The blue one for the nausea? Yes. But the pink one that stops him feeling restless because of the blue one?... I tried, Peter. I was on hold for an hour! INT. MATT’S BEDROOM - LATER THAT NIGHT 47 Matt lies in bed. Tossing. Groaning. He wakes, raises his head and searches the room - nothing - or... This is so l one of his dreams. Is he asleep? He looks down at his arm and pinches himself - hard. Awake, he sits up and looks a the glass wall across the room. Is there a shape in there

Looks harder. Yes. Definitely. Around his size - a bit smaller - standing just the other side of the glass. The shadow moves in the other chamber to the door. Matt looks at the door. It slowly swings open.  48 49 26. Matt stares into the widening blackness - He stands up - shaky - and moves towards the door - and into the darknes For a moment we see through the glass: Two figures face each other. INT. MATT’S BEDROOM - THE NEXT MORNING 48
Matt? Where are you? Matt? Billy comes down the stairs. But the bedroom is empty.
In here. Then Billy sees - the open door to the other room.
Whoa. How’d you get in there? And we see it really wasn’t a dream. The door is open.

What is this place?

Hop on. Matt's standing behind a heavy stainless steel gurney - practically gleaming considering how old it is. MATT (CONT’D) Take you for a ride. Billy gets on. Matt pulls him roughly - so he’s flat on i Matt starts turning it around - faster and faster. As he - he sees - while spinning around - glimpses of Aickman a Jonah removing a body from a coffin. The coffin then fill not with a body, but with sandbags, and re-sealed shut. He seems oblivious to his brother who’s holding on to the gurney which Matt is turning faster and faster.
Matt - slow down - Matt! Stop!  50 27.
(Descending the stairs) Dammit, what is going on down here? Matt stops. Billy nearly thrown from the gurney.
What's the matter with you?
Sorry. As their Dad steps into the bedroom and sees the open doo

I guess I loosened it, eh? (entering the room) What the hell... About three feet from the floor, along all four walls run a continuous shelf about three feet in width. In a corner there’s a dull porcelain embalming TABLE. Pile of old yellowed TOE TAGS next to a dusty glass EMBALMING PUMP. Creepy old EMBALMING TOOLS, trochars, big metal syringes scattered on the shelf. Old rust-stained PORCELAIN SINKS. Then the clincher: an old bottle labelled formaldehyde. PETER (0.S.) (CONT’D) Well now we know why the rent was so cheap. The question is -
Peter bears down on Sara, who’s trying to avoid facing hi
- what did you know and when the hell did you know it? Jesus!
